Name: Mary Jackson

Correction: Mary Jackson was actually an African American mathematician and aerospace engineer who worked at NASA. She was one of the first African American women to work as an engineer at the agency and made significant contributions to the field of aerospace engineering, particularly in the early days of the space program.

Biography: Inge Lehmann was actually a Danish seismologist and geophysicist, not a Swedish botanist and chemist. Lehmann's groundbreaking work in seismology earned her international recognition and paved the way for further advancements in geophysics.

Throughout her illustrious career, she broke numerous barriers for women in science, received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, and made significant contributions to the field of nanotechnology.

Name: Katia Krafft

Katia Krafft was a distinguished French volcanologist who, along with her husband Maurice Krafft, became renowned for their pioneering work in documenting volcanic eruptions worldwide. Born on April 17, 1942, she dedicated her life to studying and capturing the raw power of volcanoes, ultimately losing her life during a volcanic eruption in Japan in 1991.

Mary Barra is the Chairman and CEO of General Motors, not Ford Motor Company. She became the first female CEO of a major global automaker in January 2014. Washington was a trailblazing figure in the accounting profession, becoming the first African American woman to earn the prestigious title of Certified Public Accountant (CPA) in the United States in 1963. She went on to establish her own successful accounting firm in New York City, where she not only provided exceptional services but also served as a mentor and inspiration for aspiring accountants, particularly within the African American community.

Biography: Esther Duflo is actually a renowned French economist known for her research in development economics and poverty alleviation. Name: Elinor Ostrom
Elinor Ostrom was actually an American political economist known for her groundbreaking research on the governance of common pool resources, which led her to become the first woman to win the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences in 2009. Her work challenged the conventional belief that centralized regulation or privatization are the only solutions for managing shared resources effectively.

As a freed slave, she broke barriers in a male-dominated field, becoming a symbol of courage and resilience during a time when women and people of color faced significant societal limitations.

Name: Joan of Arc was actually a French peasant girl who claimed divine guidance to lead the French army to victory during the Hundred Years' War, helping Charles VII to be crowned king. Captured by the English, she was tried for heresy and burned at the stake in 1431, later becoming a symbol of French unity and a revered historical figure.
